Abandoned

abandon due to lack of time.

Instead of the undecorated commit ID can we please use the "description" style of `git log -1 --format='%h ("%s")' 421cc42892e9bd8065025382a05e3858119493ef`, which yields `421cc42892e9 ("Remove non-functional tests")`. This provides a bit more context without having to go chase up the actual change in question.
done 😊

How did you go about this? Is this a revert of the mentioned commit plus a cleanup mashed into one commit?

Why is it better to have 1 executable for all tests?

Can we please add the threshold tests separately?

for me its better to have 1 executable. 

i run the tests on the BMC, and with 1 binary its about 25 MB
whereas having 1 binary for each test suite is about 15 MB for each suite.

so its less space to have just one and takes less time to copy to the BMC.

also its more convenient to only run one program and see that all tests pass 
because thats what most people would care about in my opinion. just making a
change and seeing that the tests pass.

when there are so many tests that it takes too long or output becomes too big
then one could think about making a commandline option to only run some suites.

what do you care about?

just having multiple binaries? for what reason?
or just being able to run only a specific suite of tests?

yes its a 
- revert of the mentioned commit
- cleanup
- new tests

> yes its a 
> - revert of the mentioned commit
> - cleanup
> - new tests

So, if you can write a list of things the commit does, it suggests that each entry in the list could be its own commit 😊

However, I while expect the revert doesn't stand on its own and that some cleanup is necessary, I also suspect the addition of new tests can be its own separate change.

Essentially you should try to minimise each commit to reduce the opportunity for maintainers to say no (and thus maximise your chance of making them say yes).

> i run the tests on the BMC, and with 1 binary its about 25 MB
> whereas having 1 binary for each test suite is about 15 MB for each suite.

Okay. Are these stripped? You could massage the meson to install the tests and then use `meson install --strip` to sort them out. It might also be worth building with `meson setup -Dbuildtype=release` to see if there's much difference.

> when there are so many tests that it takes too long or output becomes too big
then one could think about making a commandline option to only run some suites.

Well, they do appear to be gtests so we can already slice-and-dice them on the command line:

https://google.github.io/googletest/advanced.html#running-test-programs-advanced-options

I guess I'm not terribly fussed about the one binary. But I was curious.

Can you please add a `Fixes:` tag in the manner of Linux? See:

1. https://docs.kernel.org/process/submitting-patches.html#using-reported-by-tested-by-reviewed-by-suggested-by-and-fixes
2. https://docs.kernel.org/process/submitting-patches.html#describe-changes
done 😊
Thanks for adding the tests back. It's a shame they were removed instead of fixed initially, but sometimes that's the easiest way to make progress. I've made a few comments.

wanted to give this another chance in the CI since
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpeci/+/63782
this was merged
In general, I support enable the tests
Can we remove the additional spaces?
Build still fails
